FIGREF17.text: Apart from a small fragment o f dentary lingual plate, the only parts o f the mandible preserved are both dentary coronoid processes. They are almost identically broken and preserve only 110 mm o f the proximal rami o f the dentaries. They appear somewhat squat when compared to other large chasmosaurines, which typically have more dorsally extended processes. The portion o f dentary lingual plate preserves positions for 18 tooth rows; however, both ends are incomplete, and the total number o f alveolar grooves cannot be determined.CHAPTER V COMPARISON WITH OTHER CHASMOSAURINESBefore the comparative discussion is presented, several chasmosaurine genera deserve mention as they are omitted from the analysis and are regarded herein as nomen dubia."Ojoceratops" of the Maastrichtian, Naashoibito Member o f the Ojo Alamo

FIGREF18.text: ; Hunt and Lehman, COMPARATIVE DISCUSSION Chasmosaurine ceratopsids are diagnosed almost entirely on the basis o f the form and ornamentation of the squamosal-parietal frill. Other aspects o f the skull, such as the size and orientation of the nasal and postorbital homcores, and the variable configuration of the intemarial components o f the premaxilla are of subordinate importance. Therefore, the few features preserved in the fragmentary skull of Bravoceratops that are thought to be of taxonomic significance are emphasized in the following comparison. Because most chasmosaurine genera are monospecific, in this discussion each genus is referred to only by its generic name except where referring to features that are known to differ between two o f its species. Frill The preserved parts of the squamosal and parietal in Bravoceratops indicate that it is a "long-frilled" chasmosaurine with long squamosals, a slender midline parietal bar, and very large parietal fenestrae. This basic frill form is comparable to that found in Chasmosaurus (= "M o jo c e ra to p sas argued by Maidment and Barrett, 2011), Vagaceratops, "Agujaceratops," Utahceratops, Coahuilaceratops, and Pentaceratops. These taxa are generally regarded as the least-derived members of Chasmosaurinae. The frill is, instead, shorter or the parietal fenestrae smaller, or both, in more derived chasmosaurines such as Kosmoceratops, Anchiceratops, Arrhinoceratops, Torosaurus, Eotriceratops, and Triceratops (= "Diceratops" or "N e d o ce ra to p sas argued by Ostrom and Wellnhofer, 1990).

FIGREF19.text: lacks the distinctive configuration of large, exaggerated epiparietals exhibited by Vagaceratops, Kosmoceratops, or Anchiceratops. The single intact epiparietal in Bravoceratops is low and elliptical and comparable in form to those bordering the squamosal. This simple, unspecialized epiparietal form is also found in Arrhinoceratops, Torosaurus, and Triceratops. However, the detached epiparietal preserved with Bravoceratops indicates that it had at least one exaggerated epiparietal, probably at each comer o f the frill, as in some specimens o f Chasmosaurus, "Agujaceratops", and Pentaceratops. Furthermore, Bravoceratops possesses a unique configuration o f midline epiparietals, with one along the distal parietal border and another on the dorsal surface at the anterior nexus o f the parietal rami. The posterior midline epiparietal is otherwise known only in Triceratops, Torosaurus utahensis, andthe "Naashoibito" parietal (referable to T. utahensis or "Ojoceratops"). The anterior midline epiparietal, detached prior to preservation, is represented by a distinct tear-drop shaped depression on the dorsal surface of the parietal in Bravoceratops. This sutural surface may have anchored a coalesced, laterally divergent pair of midline epiparietals similar to those in Anchiceratops. However, in Bravoceratops, the attachment site is so narrow transversely that it seems likely that only a single epiparietal was bonded there.

FIGREF20.text: . The skull o f Coahuilaceratops is very fragmentary, and too little of its frill is preserved to permit adequate comparison with Bravoceratops. Because Coahuilaceratops is found in broadly coeval strata nearby in Coahuila, Mexico, it is reasonable to suspect that the two chasmosaurines might be the same. The narrow and shallow nasal bridge in Bravoceratops indicates that the two are different. However, the diagnostic posterior end o f the parietal is not preserved in Coahuilaceratops, and this is the part o f the skull that differs most markedly among chasmosaurines. CHAPTER VI RELATIONSHIPS OF BRAVOCERATOPS Although the only known specimen o f Bravoceratops is fragmentary, the preserved parts are sufficient to reveal a unique combination of character states and to warrant its recognition as a unique taxon. Bravoceratops shares with Chasmosaurus, Utahceratops, and Pentaceratops 1) a long, relatively straight squamosal, 2) a slender parietal midline bar with large parietal fenestrae, and 3) one or more exaggerated epoccipitals at the posterolateral comers of frill. All other chasmosaurines have either substantially shorter or dorsally curved squamosals, a broader medial parietal with smaller (or no) parietal fenestrae, or a unique set o f exaggerated epiparietals.

FIGREF21.text: Therefore, an alternative hypothesis is that Bravoceratops may occupy a phylogenetic position more derived than either Anchiceratops or Arrhinoceratops and closer toTorosaurus. The former hypothesis would require that the posterior midline epiparietal and bifurcated quadratojugal developed independently in Bravoceratops and then again later in the Torosaurus-Triceratops lineage. The latter hypothesis would require that the slender, grooved midline parietal bar and the widely open fenestrate frill in Bravoceratops was a result of later reversal to the basal chasmosaurine condition. The consequences of either hypothesis seem objectionable, and either could be favored depending on the weight one grants each o f its presumed derived features and the perceived likelihood of their repeated development by convergence or reversal. Nevertheless, it is clear that Bravoceratops occupies an intermediate phylogenetic position between the less derived forms such as Pentaceratops, and more derived forms, such as Torosaurus or Triceratops

Possible intermediate phylogenetic positions of Bravoceratops with: (a) position among less derived and (b) more derived chasmosaurines. Adapted from Wick and Lehman (2013). Although the holotype skull and only known specimen of Bravoceratops is fragmentary, it exhibits a combination o f character states unique among chasmosaurines. It retains a long, widely open fenestrate frill comparable to that in the least derived chasmosaurines and most similar to Pentaceratops. However, the broad, fan-shaped posterior end o f the parietal and the attachment site for a dorsal midline epiparietal are derived features shared with Anchiceratops. A second midline epiparietal on the posterior edge o f the parietal and a bifurcated squamosal process on the quadratojugal are features found only in the most derived chasmosaurines, Torosaurus and Triceratops. If the tear-drop-shaped depression on the dorsal midline surface of the parietal in Bravoceratops indeed bore a single epiparietal, as hypothesized here, then this would represent a unique, derived condition. The constriction o f the nasal bridge behind the epinasal in Bravoceratops may also represent a unique, derived condition that links it

Eventually, an ever-increasing number of chasmosaurine genera, having evolved independently within a limited paleogeographic area and timeframe will, eventually, overwhelm evolutionary limitations and may require significant revisions among current chasmosaurine phylogenetic interpretations.
